I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) facility will provide project preparation support 
and capacity building for two ensuing projects in Mongolia on Developing Cross-Border Economic 
Zone (CBEZ) and Regional Improvement of Border Services (Additional Financing). The ensuing 
projects will support Mongolia’s trade and economic objectives with a focus on developing the 
country’s strategic border areas. A similar set of safeguards, financial management, economic, 
and other technical assessments is required. The TA is included in the country operations 
business plan for Mongolia, 2019–2021.1  
 
2.  Development challenges. However, Mongolia’s geographic isolation, vast and sparsely 
populated  land  area,  and  landlocked  position  pose  substantial  challenges  to  the  country’s 
development. Inadequate and poorly maintained infrastructure result to high trade and transport 
costs making Mongolia’s exports uncompetitive. Despite Mongolia’s adoption of a liberal trade 
policy, weak trade facilitation on Mongolia’s side of the border results in delays and poor supply 
chain management.2 
 
3.  Government strategy. Recent economic downturn highlighted the need to develop a 
more resilient and diversified economy that delivers sustainable growth. The TA and its ensuing 
projects are consistent and aligned with Mongolia’s Sustainable Development Vision 20303 and 
Action Plan of the Government of Mongolia in 2016–2020.4 These include actions to: (i) boost the 
operations of free economic zones and support foreign and domestic investments; (ii) promote 
trade and manufacturing at international trade zones and border port areas; (iii) improve the 
border  points  and  near  border  infrastructure;  and  (iv)  intensify  economic  integration  and 
infrastructure networks and create enabling conditions for foreign trade.   
 
4.  Key problems and issues at the borders. Several border crossing points (BCPs) of 
Mongolia are part of the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) corridor 4 which 
connects Mongolia with the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and Russian Federation (Russia).5 
However, underdeveloped infrastructure and adverse weather during winter impede efficient road 
transport along the routes. In 2017, the Corridor Performance Measurement and Monitoring 
(CPMM) Report documented that inbound traffic at the Zamyn-Uud BCP coming from Tianjin in 
PRC takes more than a day to cross the border. Waiting due to shortage of railway wagons, 
marshalling, transfer of materials and technical inspection contribute to the delay. Meanwhile, 
infrastructure, facilities and equipment at two strategic BCPs identified by the Government, 
namely, Bichigt bordering the PRC in the East and Borshoo bordering the Russia in the West, are 
currently outdated and inadequate to maintain border clearance and immigration protection 
standards.   
                                                
1  ADB. 2018. Country Operations Business Plan 2019–2021: Mongolia. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Mongolia, 2017–2020 Sustaining Inclusive Growth in a Period of Economic 
Difficulty. Manila. 
3  Government of Mongolia. 2016. Mongolia Sustainable Development Vision 2030. Ulaanbaatar.    
4  Government of Mongolia. 2016. Action Program of the Government of Mongolia, 2016–2020. Ulaanbaatar. 
5  Subcorridor 4a lies in western Mongolia and provides a transit route between the Russian Federation to the PRC.  
Subcorridor 4b is the most active and covers the key north–south railway of more than 1,000 km, providing an 
important transit and import–export route to the PRC. Subcorridor 4c is the route to the east that connects 
Ulaanbaatar to Chifeng, a major PRC railway node, and Jinzhou, a seaport in the northeastern region of the PRC. 
The route is designed to alleviate Mongolia’s sole reliance on Tianjin, the nearest seaport, for its commercial 
shipments.

2 
 
 
5.  As  early  as  1995,  the  Government  introduced  free  zones6 to  promote  economic 
development in border areas and support Mongolia’s transition into a market economy. However, 
the three free zones established so far in Altanbulag (Selenge aimag [province]), Zamyn-Uud 
(Dornogobi aimag), and Tsagaannuur (Bayan-Ulgii aimag), have limited or no investment and 
operations. Underdeveloped infrastructure and facilities, weak capacity and poor policy and 
planning coordination, have weakened the investment attractiveness of these free zones despite 
the strong political support and strategic locations. 
 
6.  Efforts were sought to reinvigorate and expand the development of the free zones 
including through the amendment of the Law of Mongolia on Free Zones in 2015. In April 2018, 
the Government also signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the PRC to develop CBEZ 
which covers the free zones of Zamyn-Uud and  Erlian in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. 
Such zones are increasingly becoming part of economic corridor development among CAREC 
countries. Furthermore, the Government signed a trilateral plan to develop an economic corridor 
with the PRC and Russia which aims to strengthen transport, logistics and trade connectivity while 
promoting Mongolia’s position as a transit country.  
 
7.  Existing and potential regional arrangements further present opportunity to enhance 
Mongolia’s linkage with the global and regional value chains. For instance, Mongolia’s exports 
enjoy generalized system of preferences from the European Union and preferential tariffs under 
an economic partnership agreement with Japan.7 Mongolia is considering free trade agreements 
with the Eurasian Economic Union, the PRC, and Republic of Korea. Mongolia is an active 
member of regional cooperation and integration (RCI) initiatives such as the CAREC Program 
and the Greater Tumen Initiative.8  
 
8.  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  support.  The  Country  Partnership  Strategy  for 
Mongolia, 2017–2020 emphasizes the need to improve physical connectivity and trade facilitation 
to enhance the competitiveness of the Mongolian economy (footnote 2). Prior and ongoing ADB 
investment and technical assistance focused on improving transport connectivity, trade facilitation 
and border management. A regional logistics development project, which was completed and 
operational in October 2018, provides multimodal facilities for road-to-road, road-to-rail, and rail-
to-rail transshipment and modern customs and quarantine facilities to connect Mongolia’s road 
and rail links in Zamyn-Uud to the PRC.9 An ongoing project aims to improve inspection and 
control systems of Mongolian border authorities (in Dakhan-Uul, Altanbulag, and Zamyn-Uud) to 
increase agri-food trade;10 while another projects will support the upgrade and improve border 
facilities and equipment at key BCPs including Altanbulag and Zamyn-Uud.11  
                                                
6   Free zone means a part of the territory of Mongolia, deemed to fall outside the customs territory for the purposes of 
customs duties and other taxes, adopting a special treatment of business activity (Article 3, The Law of Mongolia on 
Free Zones, as amended and restated on 12 February 2015).  
7  Under the Japan-Mongolia economic partnership agreement which entered into force in June 2016, 5,700 types of 
goods from Mongolia and 9,300 types of goods from Japan are exempted or with gradual elimination of customs 
duties. Agricultural products, textiles and leather products, and heavy industrial products from Mongolia also enjoy 
preferential tariff conditions in Japan.  
8  An  intergovernmental  cooperation  mechanism  among  Mongolia,  the  PRC,  Republic  of  Korea,  and  Russian 
Federation, supported by the United Nations Development Programme. 
9  ADB. 2016. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to Mongolia for 
Regional Logistics Development Project. Manila.  
10 ADB. 2016. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to Mongolia for 
Regional Upgrades of Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures for Trade Project. Manila.  
11 ADB. 2016. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to Mongolia for 
Regional Improvement of Border Services. Manila.

3 
 
 
 
9.  The ensuing projects to be supported by the TA will not only enhance economic activity in 
Mongolia but improve trade and investment linkages with its neighboring countries, particularly, 
with the PRC and Russia. Such will support implementation of Mongolia’s agreements with the 
two countries and as a spillover, promote development of regional value chain within the CAREC 
corridor 4. Specifically, the CBEZ project will help facilitate the development of export-oriented 
production, transport and logistics services in the Mongolia CBEZ in the Zamyn-Uud and improve 
trade and tourism services with the PRC in Erlian. This TA is also linked to the subproject on 
Erlian CBEZ infrastructure development which is part of the proposed RCI projects in the PRC.12  
 
10.  The Regional Improvement of Border Services project (Additional Financing) will upgrade 
and improve facilities and border equipment at two BCPs, i.e., Bichigt and Borshoo, which are 
anticipated to become increasingly functional gateways for cross-border trade as well as cross-
border people-to-people exchanges.  
 
11.  The TA directly supports the implementation of ADB’s Strategy 2030 operational priority 
of fostering RCI.13 It is aligned with the framework of CAREC 2030 Strategy14 which aims to 
support CAREC countries including Mongolia in integrating further with the global economy 
through increased market access, greater diversification, and stronger institutions for trade.15  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
12.  The transaction TA will support the preparation and capacity-building of the ensuing 
projects with the following outputs: 
 
13.  Output 1: Technical feasibility assessments conducted. The TA will support project 
preparation through feasibility studies to ensure the technical soundness and maximize the RCI 
dimension, whenever possible, of the project design. Key activities will include: (i) feasibility for 
CBEZ taking into consideration the approved Masterplan for Zamyn-Uud free zone and (ii) 
feasibility assessment of a single window electronic services for the administrative processes in 
the Mongolia CBEZ and interoperability of its port processing system with the PRC side of the 
CBEZ.   
  
14.  Output 2: Investment plan and procurement packages completed. The TA will support 
economic,  financial  and  governance  due  diligence  of  the  ensuing  projects  to  assess  their 
economic and financial viability. Key activities will include: (i) conducting financial and economic 
analyses including regional and cross-border benefits of the projects; (ii) carrying out financial 
management  assessment  of  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  and  the  project 
implementing entities and recommending measures where necessary to strengthen their financial 
management system for project implementation; (iii) preparing the procurement plan; and (iv) 
carrying out procurement risk assessments of the executing and implementing agencies. 
 
15.  Output 3: Safeguard due diligence completed. The TA will support the safeguard due 
diligence of the ensuing projects covering environment, resettlement, and indigenous peoples in 
                                                
12 ADB. 2017. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Preparing Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Projects. Manila.  
13 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
14 ADB. 2017. CAREC 2030: Connecting the Region for Shared and Sustainable Development. Manila. 
15 ADB. 2018. CAREC Integrated Trade Agenda 2030 and Rolling Strategic Action Plan 2018-2020. Manila.

4 
 
accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement.16 The TA will also support assessment of 
poverty, gender, and other social development issues related to the ensuing projects. Key 
activities include preparing, as appropriate: (i) environment impact assessments and/or initial 
environmental examinations; (ii) resettlement plans; (iii) ethnic minority development plan; (iv) 
stakeholder  analysis,  participation  plan,  and  conduct  stakeholder  workshops;  (v)  gender 
assessment and gender action plan in line with ADB’s Guidelines for Gender Mainstreaming 
Categories of ADB Project (2012);17 and (vi) social, and poverty assessments and action plans 
including an assessment of workers situation related to wages, skills training needs, employment 
opportunities, and access to social services. 
 
16.  Output 4: Business strategy roadmap and market analysis prepared. The TA will 
support preparation of a roadmap for CBEZ development. The roadmap will include business 
development, investment promotion and a marketing plan based on a market survey analysis. 
The market survey will identify priority industries/sectors and factors to attract and sustain 
investors and businesses in the CBEZ. The RCI dimension of the ensuing projects will be 
enhanced by creating synergies with related projects in neighboring countries. The roadmap in 
Zamyn-Uud free zone may be used as a model to other free zones in Mongolia.  
 
17.  Output  5:  Project  management  capacity  of  the  executing  and  implementing 
agencies improved. The TA will strengthen the capacity of the executing and implementing 
agencies and project implementing entities for project preparation and implementation. Key 
activities will include: (i) assessing the institutional set up and identifying gaps in capacities of the 
executing and implementing agencies with regard to project preparation and implementation; (ii) 
preparing an institutional development and capacity building plan; (iii) developing operational 
guidelines for enhanced inter-agency coordination and processes; and (iii) organizing trainings 
on project management as well as best practices on integrated border management, economic 
corridor development, CBEZ or free zones, and trade and investment promotion.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $758,000 of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF−6). The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 1. The Government of Mongolia will provide counterpart support in the form of 
counterpart staff, secretarial assistance, domestic transportation, provision of relevant data and 
reports for the consultants’ use, and other in-kind contributions. The Government was informed 
that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing projects. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  ADB will administer the TA. The East Asia Department’s Public Management, Financial 
Sector, and Regional Cooperation Division will lead the TA implementation and will select, 
administer, evaluate, and supervise the consultants and their outputs to be delivered for the 
ensuing projects. The Deputy Prime Minister’s Office and the Ministry of Finance will be the 
executing agencies. The Governor’s Office of Zamyn-Uud Free Zone and Customs General 
Administration of Mongolia will be the implementing agencies. The executing and implementing 
agencies of the ensuing projects are expected to exercise strong ownership in implementing the 
TA, with full support of the ADB project team members and consultants. The TA activities for an 
                                                
16 ADB. 2009. Safeguard Policy Statement. Manila. 
17 ADB. 2012. Guidelines for Gender Mainstreaming Categories of ADB Projects. Manila.

5 
 
 
ensuing project will start only after ADB approves the project concept paper of the ensuing project. 
The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1. 
 
Table 1: Implementation Arrangements

ADB = Asian Development Bank, CBEZ = cross-border economic zone, QCBS = quality- and cost-based selection, 
RIBS = regional improvement of border services, TA = technical assistance.   
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
20.  Consulting services. The TA will engage individual and/or firm through QCBS (80:20) 
international and national consultants for a total of 43 person-months for preparation of the 
ensuing projects. The consultants will undertake work in the areas of environment, climate change, 
social safeguards, social development and gender assessment, economic analyses, financial 
management,  procurement,  border,  civil  engineering  and  urban  infrastructure,  regional 
cooperation and integrated trade facilitation, business development strategy, market survey, 
blockchain architecture and artificial intelligence, and institutional development. Same set of 
consultants will be engaged in some items (Appendix 2).  
 
21.  ADB  will  engage  the  consultants  following  the  ADB  Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as 
amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff 
instructions.18 Lump-sum or output-based contracts will be considered for consulting services 
wherever possible to reduce administrative burden and improve the economy, efficiency, and 
value for money.  
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
Mongolia for Preparing Regional Cooperation and Integration Projects, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.   
 
 
                                                
18  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
